articles.headline: Iranian Hackers Target Trump Campaign as Threats to 2020 Mount
articles.snippet: The news, according to two people with knowledge of the attacks, followed a Microsoft report that said hackers had targeted a campaign, U.S. officials and journalists.
articles.abstract: The news, according to two people with knowledge of the attacks, followed a Microsoft report that said hackers had targeted a campaign, U.S. officials and journalists.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — The 2020 presidential election is still 13 months away, but already Iranians are following in the footsteps of Russia and have begun cyberattacks aimed at disrupting the campaigns.
articles.byline: By Nicole Perlroth and David E. Sanger

articles.headline: Saudi Arabia and Iran Make Quiet Openings to Head Off War
articles.snippet: Weeks after the Middle East seemed on the verge of war, Saudi Arabia and Iran are seeking ways to ease tensions. A warming relationship could have far-reaching consequences.
articles.abstract: Weeks after the Middle East seemed on the verge of war, Saudi Arabia and Iran are seeking ways to ease tensions. A warming relationship could have far-reaching consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: After years of growing hostility and competition for influence, Saudi Arabia and Iran have taken steps toward indirect talks to try to reduce the tensions that have brought the Middle East to the brink of war, according to officials from several countries involved in the efforts.
articles.byline: By Farnaz Fassihi and Ben Hubbard

articles.headline: Bernie Sanders Had Heart Attack, His Doctors Say as He Leaves Hospital
articles.snippet: “After two and a half days in the hospital, I feel great, and after taking a short time off, I look forward to getting back to work,” Mr. Sanders said.
articles.abstract: “After two and a half days in the hospital, I feel great, and after taking a short time off, I look forward to getting back to work,” Mr. Sanders said.
articles.lead_paragraph: Senator Bernie Sanders had a heart attack this week, his presidential campaign said on Friday as he left a Las Vegas hospital, following three days of near silence from the candidate and his advisers about his health.

articles.headline: 2nd Official Is Weighing Whether to Blow the Whistle on Trump’s Ukraine Dealings
articles.snippet: The official, a member of the intelligence community, was interviewed by the inspector general to corroborate the original whistle-blower’s account.
articles.abstract: The official, a member of the intelligence community, was interviewed by the inspector general to corroborate the original whistle-blower’s account.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — A second intelligence official who was alarmed by President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine is weighing whether to file his own formal whistle-blower complaint and testify to Congress, according to two people briefed on the matter.
articles.byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: China Masters Political Propaganda for the Instagram Age
articles.snippet: Leveraging celebrities, the know-how of tech companies and images built for social media, the Communist Party can effectively stir patriotism among the youth.
articles.abstract: Leveraging celebrities, the know-how of tech companies and images built for social media, the Communist Party can effectively stir patriotism among the youth.
articles.lead_paragraph: Lu Yingxin has been singing “My People, My Country” for the past week. An earnest propaganda anthem from 1985, the song typically wouldn’t stand a chance against Taylor Swift, K-pop and other modern tunes the 18-year-old college student and her friends like to listen to.

articles.headline: ‘A Caricature of the Patriarchy’: Argentine Feminists Remake Tango
articles.snippet: A group of activists is trying to make tango less dogmatic about traditional gender roles, and more assertive about rooting out sexual harassment and assault.
articles.abstract: A group of activists is trying to make tango less dogmatic about traditional gender roles, and more assertive about rooting out sexual harassment and assault.
articles.lead_paragraph: BUENOS AIRES — Liliana Furió’s ruby red flat shoes glided across the dance floor in swift, assured moves, making her baggy pants sway gently.

articles.headline: A Provocateur of the Hong Kong Protests Gains Growing Stature
articles.snippet: In a city roiled by political animus, Junius Ho, a pro-Beijing lawmaker, is gleefully fueling the divide by praising the police and demonizing the protesters.
articles.abstract: In a city roiled by political animus, Junius Ho, a pro-Beijing lawmaker, is gleefully fueling the divide by praising the police and demonizing the protesters.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — From afar, the red brick sidewalk along King’s Road in Hong Kong appears to be covered with a mottled white carpet that stretches for dozens of yards. Closer up, the white reveals itself to be a mosaic made up of sheets of paper glued to the pavement, each featuring a bespectacled man with a self-confident smile.

articles.headline: Biden Faced His Biggest Challenge, and Struggled to Form a Response
articles.snippet: As Trump made unfounded allegations about Biden and his son, the former vice president was torn over what to do. He now looks more vulnerable than at any point in the campaign.
articles.abstract: As Trump made unfounded allegations about Biden and his son, the former vice president was torn over what to do. He now looks more vulnerable than at any point in the campaign.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr.’s presidential campaign was under attack, and he and his advisers were torn over what to do.
articles.byline: By Jonathan Martin, Alexander Burns and Katie Glueck

articles.headline: The Ukrainian Ex-Prosecutor Behind the Impeachment Furor
articles.snippet: President Trump’s allies sought help from a prosecutor with no formal legal training and a long history of wielding the law in personal battles.
articles.abstract: President Trump’s allies sought help from a prosecutor with no formal legal training and a long history of wielding the law in personal battles.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — As soon as he got the invitation from Rudolph W. Giuliani, President Trump’s personal lawyer, it was abundantly clear to him what Mr. Trump’s allies were after.
articles.byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Andrew Higgins and Michael Schwirtz

articles.headline: Barr and a Top Prosecutor Cast a Wide Net in Reviewing the Russia Inquiry
articles.snippet: The attorney general and a veteran prosecutor, John H. Durham, have charted an unusual course that could bolster President Trump’s pet theories about the Russia investigation.
articles.abstract: The attorney general and a veteran prosecutor, John H. Durham, have charted an unusual course that could bolster President Trump’s pet theories about the Russia investigation.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After a jet carrying Attorney General William P. Barr touched down in Rome last month, some diplomats and intelligence officials at the American Embassy were unsure why he had come. They were later surprised, two officials said, to discover that he had circumvented protocols in arranging the trip, where he met with Italian political and intelligence officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti, Adam Goldman and Katie Benner

articles.headline: Elizabeth Warren’s Big Challenge: Winning Black Voters
articles.snippet: African-Americans were essential to Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton winning competitive primaries like Ms. Warren faces in 2020. For now, Joe Biden has far deeper support.
articles.abstract: African-Americans were essential to Hillary Clinton, Barack Obama and Bill Clinton winning competitive primaries like Ms. Warren faces in 2020. For now, Joe Biden has far deeper support.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCK HILL, S.C. — For her most recent rally in South Carolina, Senator Elizabeth Warren chose Clinton College, a historically black institution in this racially diverse city. Her campaign handed out signs reading, “African Americans With Warren.” And in smaller print: “Black issues are American issues.”

articles.headline: Addicted to Screens? That’s Really a You Problem
articles.snippet: Nir Eyal, who wrote the industry manual for hooking people on tech, now has a recipe to free you — even though it was your fault to begin with.
articles.abstract: Nir Eyal, who wrote the industry manual for hooking people on tech, now has a recipe to free you — even though it was your fault to begin with.
articles.lead_paragraph: Nir Eyal does not for a second regret writing Silicon Valley’s tech engagement how-to, “Hooked: How to Build Habit-Forming Products,” even as he now has a new book out on how to free ourselves of that same addiction.

articles.headline: Legal Team Says It Represents a Second Whistle-Blower Over Trump and Ukraine
articles.snippet: The new whistle-blower, who is said to have firsthand knowledge of the president’s dealings, has been interviewed by the intelligence community’s inspector general’s office.
articles.abstract: The new whistle-blower, who is said to have firsthand knowledge of the president’s dealings, has been interviewed by the intelligence community’s inspector general’s office.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An intelligence official with “firsthand knowledge” has provided information related to President Trump’s dealings with Ukraine and is now protected from retaliation as a whistle-blower, lawyers representing the official said on Sunday, confirming that a second individual has come forward in the matter.
articles.byline: By Annie Karni and Nicholas Fandos

articles.headline: How Boeing vs. Airbus Became Trump vs. Europe
articles.snippet: Boeing won a long-running trade dispute with Airbus, but it came with complications for a company still dealing with the fallout from two deadly accidents.
articles.abstract: Boeing won a long-running trade dispute with Airbus, but it came with complications for a company still dealing with the fallout from two deadly accidents.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just weeks after his inauguration, President Trump toured Boeing’s factory in North Charleston, S.C., holding a rally with workers, admiring a new 787 Dreamliner and calling on the company to bring down the cost of new Air Force One planes.

articles.headline: Overwhelmed or Ill Informed, 70,000 Wildfire Victims May Get Nothing
articles.snippet: Lawyers say PG&E’s bankruptcy process in California is pre-empting the claims of tens of thousands who suffered losses in fires linked to its equipment.
articles.abstract: Lawyers say PG&E’s bankruptcy process in California is pre-empting the claims of tens of thousands who suffered losses in fires linked to its equipment.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — After a succession of devastating wildfires in the last four years, tens of thousands of Californians — many with broken spirits, many homeless — may now lose out on compensation from the company that was to blame.
articles.byline: By Ivan Penn and Lauren Hepler

articles.headline: Nissan’s Crisis Goes Much Deeper Than Carlos Ghosn
articles.snippet: Two insiders who brought down Carlos Ghosn were involved with improper payments, an inquiry found. The company’s full board never heard about it.
articles.abstract: Two insiders who brought down Carlos Ghosn were involved with improper payments, an inquiry found. The company’s full board never heard about it.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOKYO — An outside law firm investigating problems at Nissan, the troubled Japanese automaker, this summer discovered some potentially explosive information.
articles.byline: By Ben Dooley and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: In Kashmir, a Race Against Death, With No Way to Call a Doctor
articles.snippet: Medical personnel in Kashmir say preventable deaths are happening because of blocked streets, medicine shortages, and a phone and internet blockade by India.
articles.abstract: Medical personnel in Kashmir say preventable deaths are happening because of blocked streets, medicine shortages, and a phone and internet blockade by India.
articles.lead_paragraph: HEEVAN, Kashmir — Saja Begum was cooking dinner when her son walked into the kitchen with a stricken look on his face. “Mom,” he said. “I have been bitten by a snake. I am going to die.”
articles.byline: By Sameer Yasir and Jeffrey Gettleman

articles.headline: Pushed by Security Concerns and Trump, Germany Weighs a New Fuel
articles.snippet: The country’s first liquefied natural gas terminal could bring imports from shale fields in the United States and elsewhere.
articles.abstract: The country’s first liquefied natural gas terminal could bring imports from shale fields in the United States and elsewhere.
articles.lead_paragraph: WILHELMSHAVEN, Germany — A jetty here juts out nearly a mile into the Wadden Sea from Germany’s low-lying northern coast. Now used by a chemical plant, the pier could become the site of the country’s first liquefied natural gas terminal.

articles.headline: Trump Throws Middle East Policy Into Turmoil Over Syria
articles.snippet: After criticism that he was allowing a Turkish incursion into northern Syria, the president pivoted, saying he would prevent Turkey from going too far.
articles.abstract: After criticism that he was allowing a Turkish incursion into northern Syria, the president pivoted, saying he would prevent Turkey from going too far.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump threw Middle East policy into turmoil on Monday with a series of conflicting signals after his vow to withdraw American forces from the region touched off an uprising among congressional Republicans and protests by America’s allies.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Lara Jakes
